metadata.title: How Phone Sprint Timing Achieves ~4ms Accuracy
metadata.description: Learn how TrackSpeed uses your phone's camera to deliver millisecond-accurate sprint timing — no extra equipment required.

heroSubtitle: Your phone already has everything needed for precision sprint timing — a high frame rate camera, precise gyroscope, and powerful processor. Here's what that enables.

subFrame.title: Sub-Frame Precision
subFrame.desc: Athletes rarely cross the gate at the exact moment a frame is captured. Our system analyzes multiple frames to pinpoint the crossing moment between frames — achieving sub-millisecond interpolation accuracy that goes far beyond the camera's native frame interval.

corrections.title: Physics-Based Corrections
corrections.desc: Phone cameras scan each frame from top to bottom over several milliseconds, introducing a timing offset depending on where the athlete appears in frame. We automatically correct for this and other hardware-level timing artifacts to eliminate systematic error.

clockSync.title: Multi-Device Clock Sync
clockSync.desc: When using two phones — one at the start and one at the finish — their clocks need to agree within milliseconds. Our synchronization protocol achieves ±3-5ms alignment between devices. During sync, keep both phones within about 10 meters of each other for best results. Once synced, move them as far apart as needed.

bodyTracking.title: Body Tracking, Not Beam Breaking
bodyTracking.desc: Laser gates trigger on whatever breaks the beam first — an outstretched arm, a knee, or the chest. This varies by running form and creates inconsistency. TrackSpeed tracks the chest crossing the line, matching how official timing works.

accuracy.title: The Result
accuracy.label: Effective timing accuracy
accuracy.desc: Sub-frame interpolation, physics corrections, and clock synchronization combine to deliver timing precision that rivals dedicated hardware — using just your phone.

professionalComparison.title: How This Compares
professionalComparison.laserNote: *Laser gates trigger with sub-millisecond speed, but inconsistent trigger points (arm vs chest) can cause 50-200ms variation between runs for the same athlete.
